Crime_Name: Violation of Canada Labour Code and COHSR
Legal_Issue: Whether the court can issue mandamus to compel the Minister of Labour or Health and Safety Officer to prosecute Air Canada or issue a direction under the Canada Labour Code
Governing_Law: Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations (COHSR)
Application_Facts: Unions alleged Air Canada violated workplace safety regulations; HSO investigated and found no violation
Decision_Outcome: Mandamus claims dismissed; judicial review for certiorari allowed to proceed
Remedy_Requested: Mandamus to compel prosecution or issuance of a direction
Court_Ruling: Mandamus is not available to compel discretionary actions such as prosecution or issuance of directions unless there is flagrant impropriety
Defendant_Behavior: Air Canada allegedly violated workplace safety regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged non-compliance with safety standards under federal labour legislation
Legal_Standard: Mandamus unavailable for discretionary acts without flagrant impropriety; prosecutorial discretion subject to review only in exceptional cases
Assessment_Factor: Reasonableness of HSO's decision not to issue a direction or prosecute
Applicable_Legislation: Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations (COHSR)
Procedural_Issue: Motion to strike mandamus claims in a judicial review application
Review_Standard: Certiorari to assess reasonableness of administrative decision
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of the Canada Labour Code and COHSR relating to health and safety enforcement
Application_Basis: Judicial review based on alleged failure to enforce regulatory compliance
Evidence_Assessed: HSO's determination that no violation occurred
Relief_Sought: Compel enforcement action by Minister of Labour or HSO
Governing_Rule: Mandamus cannot compel discretionary administrative decisions absent flagrant impropriety
Harm_Assessment: Alleged risk to worker safety due to regulatory non-compliance
Cause_Description: Unions sought enforcement of safety regulations against Air Canada following HSO's decision not to act
Evidence_Handling: Court relied on administrative record and HSO investigation findings
Legal_Provision_Violated: Provisions of the Canada Labour Code and COHSR related to occupational health and safety
Legal_Provision: Canada Labour Code, Part II â€“ Occupational Health and Safety
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canada Labour Code
Evidence_Assessment: HSO's conclusion that no violation existed was accepted as within administrative discretion
Decision_Rationale: Judicial intervention via mandamus inappropriate where statutory discretion exists and no evidence of impropriety or unreasonableness is shown
Decision_Making_Body: Health and Safety Officer (HSO) under the Canada Labour Code
Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard for issuing mandamus: requires ministerial (non-discretionary) duty; not applicable to prosecutorial or enforcement discretion
